utterances: All right, I got my pack of snus.
Bajit pops the tin open to show me what's inside.
As you can see, these are tiny cloth packages.
Tiny cloth packages that look kind of like tea bags.
But instead of tea, each bag is filled with flavored tobacco.
Bajit pulls one out and slips it under his upper lip on the side of his mouth.
There is a slight tingling sensation.
It has mint flavor - nice to have a snus right now, yeah.
Bajit says when he can't smoke a cigarette or a cigar, snus is an easier way to get a little nicotine and the taste of tobacco.
And snus doesn't make him have to spit like traditional chewing tobacco does.
Snus has been around for a while, but it's now become the focus of an intense public health debate.
The company that makes snus wants the FDA to let the company remove most of the health warnings on its tins and say snus is safer than cigarettes.
Lars Erik Rutqvist is the top scientist at Swedish Match.
...But fascinating.
Jennifer, thanks so much for talking to us.
Thank you.
(Singing) Don't want a doll, no dinky tinker toy.
I want a hippopotamus...
(LAUGHTER)
Well, thank you for that.
That was the best hippo story of the year by far that we got here.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""I WANT A HIPPOPOTAMUS FOR CHRISTMAS"")
(Singing) Hippopotamus for Christmas.
I don't...
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
This past week, the notorious Jack Kevorkian emerged from prison.

The man known as Dr. Death declared that he would continue to argue that the terminally and chronically ill have the right to the assistance of a physician to end their lives, but he said he would no longer do it.
While Kevorkian was behind bars, the debate over physician-assisted suicide evolved.
It's now legal in one state - Oregon.
And this week, the California Assembly considers a similar measure.
So after he served his sentence, what do you think about Jack Kevorkian?
Did he help his cause or hurt it?
Do patients find a way to end their suffering illegally, and do they get help?
And where do you stand on legalization?
Our number here in Washington is 800-989-8255.
That's 800-989-TALK.
Email is talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.
Later in the program, Scooter Libby gets two and a half years in prison.
What do prisoners think about his crime and his punishment?
But first, Jack Kevorkian and physician-assisted suicide.
Joining us now is Dr. Linda Ganzini.
She's professor of psychiatry and medicine at Oregon Health and Science, and joins us from her office in Portland, Oregon.
Nice to have you on the program today.
Thank you very much for asking me.
And, Linda, before we get started, Jack Kevorkian held a news conference about an hour ago.
He was asked if he thought he might renew his activities after he completes his parole, whether he would participate in another assisted suicide.
(Soundbite of news conference)
When I entered prison, I said I'd never do it again.
There's no time limit.
I will not do it again because it would be counterproductive.
What would it serve?
What purpose?
More prosecutions, more dodging of prosecutor, more lies, more false imprisonments.
It's not worth it.
It's now up to the people to fight for their right, and this is a right.
It's a natural right.
You're born with that right.
Jack Kevorkian speaking about an hour ago at a news conference.
And, Linda, you've had a lot of experience in this field.
How do people react now to the name, Jack Kevorkian?
Well, I think he is increasingly seen as a historical figure.
He got a great deal of notoriety.
He got a great deal of attention to this issue.
But the issue has evolved.
And I don't think people believe that he represents, you know, what's going on in Oregon or the Oregon's Death with Dignity Act.
And I know that you've also surveyed doctors in Oregon about their attitudes on assisted suicide.
Is Jack Kevorkian in any way typical?
I think that he is, you know, on an extreme.
I think in Oregon, the physicians, health care professionals are still divided in their views about it.
Though many of the worries they had about the law has not come to pass.
I think there's people at both ends of the spectrum who are still very vocal.
But for the most part, Oregon has gone on and tried to really overall improve care of the terminally ill.
And people - only a very small proportion of people want assisted suicide.
And I should say there's an important distinction.

One of the things that Jack Kevorkian talked about was not only the terminally ill but the chronically ill people suffering great pain, but who are not under a diagnosis that they were going to be dying any time soon.
And that certainly not what the law calls for in Oregon.
That's right.
The Oregon law restricts assisted suicide to people with an estimated less than six months of life.
Most of the people who choose the law have cancer.
A second physician needs to confirm that life expectancy.
So - and Jack Kevorkian included people with chronic illness.
Another thing is that Jack Kevorkian practice euthanasia.
He actively killed people where Oregon law specifies that the person has to be able to take the medication on their own.
Now, in the time that he's been in prison, I know you've conducted surveys on public attitudes towards physician aid in dying.
Where do people stand on this issue?
And I know it's not a simple question.
It's not a simple question.
It's very - the kinds of results you get are very sensitive to how you ask the question.
In Oregon there's a clear core third of the population that continues to oppose assisted suicide.
For the most part, for moral reasons, I think that the people, even among people who support it - physicians who support it - only a minority are willing to write these prescriptions.
So I think there's a, you know, there's a middle group that has fair amount of ambivalence about the law.
I was also curious to see, as you conducted the survey, of those who have applied for this right to physician-assisted suicide, not all have availed themselves of the opportunity.
That's right.
Only about one in 10 people who may get explicit request to a physician actually dies of assisted suicide.
Some people wait until too late in the course of their illness.
There's a 15-day waiting period.
Often, they lose the ability to carry through before they die.
Some simply can't find a willing physician.
Some get the medication and find that they really don't need to use it.
Soâ€¦
Okay.

As we continue to look at this, does Oregon feel, and is Oregon, do you think - obviously you know that this is being under consideration at the moment in California - is this a beginning of a wave of expansion, do you think?
Hi, it's nice to be here.
With your own Hermitage Fund that you run, this is an investment fund in Russia that you continue to run.
It's got more than three billion dollars in assets, I believe.
How can you continue to do business in a country like this, where it doesn't look as though there are any kind of rules?
Well, in my case, what I did was I took my money out of Russia.
We run three billion dollars, but 95 percent of it is out of Russia because I agree with you.
It's a place where there are no rules, where there is no property rights.
In this case, BP struck a deal with these Russian partners.
It wanted to be the western company that would be operating in the Russian oilfields.
There are huge oil reserves there.
This is a place where a petroleum company would want to be.
So they had to agree to these terms or else they couldn't get in.
When they started their business there, it was all looking very good for about five years.
But as oil prices rose and as people got more and more excited, that's where the trouble's begun for them right now.
With oil above 120 dollars a barrel, everybody wants a piece of that action.
It may be that the Russian government wants a piece.
They've had something like 14 different raids by law enforcement agencies trying to take their stuff away.
Has BP called you up and said, hey, you used to run a pretty successful venture there.
What should we do?
You know, it's interesting.
Whenever anyone has trouble in Russia, the last thing they want to do is call up somebody else who's had trouble in Russia because nobody wants to associate themselves with any other problems.
Well, what would you advise them?
I mean, this is a big, big company with a lot of money on the line in Russia.
What would you tell them to do?
Well, if you look at BP's situation, it's very dire at the moment because they get about - I think about 30 percent of their reserves come from this joint venture.
And so they have no choice but to fight until the bitter end.
And that's apparently what they're doing.
My advice is carry on fighting.
Don't roll over.
I don't operate in the financial world in the way that you do.
I just read about it.
But when was the last time you knew of a big venture that was run by a chief executive officer who was in an undisclosed location in central Europe?
I think it's unprecedented, and it's an absolute damning statement about the state of business in Russia at the moment.
Bill Browder runs the Hermitage Capital Management Fund, formerly heavily invested in Russia.
Now, not so much.
Bill, thanks so much.
Thank you.
From NPR News, it's Day to Day.
As we mentioned earlier in the program, there are some good economic news today that's helping the stock market recover a bit from yesterday's steep losses.
The government reports that orders for durable goods, things like furniture and refrigerators, were up in June.
The increase was definitely not expected given the current sluggish economy.
Marketplace's John Dimsdale joins us.
And John, what are people saying about why manufacturing has turned around so strongly?
Well, they're not really sure.
I got a lot of different explanations.
These orders for big-ticket manufactured goods were strong across the board, up eight-tenths of a percent, although that number got a big boost from especially heavy defense orders.
If you take out the tanks and the planes and the weapons, the overall picture wasn't quite as rosy but still good.
